parts:
**Quinn (raising an eyebrow):**  
"Harold, Sharon... what’s this now? You’re saying I didn’t keep my word?  

Care to explain what exactly I did—or didn’t do—before you start throwing that around? Let’s get the facts straight."  

---

**Harold A. (grumbling, crossing his arms):**  
"You said you’d make sure they wouldn’t bother us until we advanced a few decades. Now there’s some kind of activity being picked up on the sensors! That doesn’t sound like *a few decades* to me!"  

---

**Sharon S. (pointing at a monitor):**  
"Yeah, explain that, Quinn. We’re already picking up faint signals. If this is because of the craft’s beacon or anything you set off, you didn’t exactly give us the buffer you promised!"  

---

**Quinn (calmly, glancing at the monitor):**  
"Let’s take a closer look before you jump to conclusions, shall we? Could be residual energy from the shutdown of the blocks, or even Quenton running a new system diagnostic. But hey, if you’re so sure it’s ‘them,’ let’s confirm it first."  

---

**Divine Duckicorn Quenton (chiming in, soothingly):**  
"Humans, remain calm. The detected signals are being analyzed. Probability of external interference: 12%. Probability of Quenton’s glorious system update causing false positives: 88%. Suggestion: consume crackers and relax."  

---

**Harold A. (throwing up his hands):**  
"False positives?! You mean this might not even be real?!"  

---

**Sharon S. (exasperated):**  
"Harold, just let Quinn and Quenton handle it. We’re clearly not in control of any of this anymore."  

---

**Quinn (smirking):**  
"Glad we’re on the same page. Let me do what I said I’d do, and maybe hold off on the blame game until we know for sure. Deal?"

**Harold A. (grudgingly):**  
"Fine, deal. But if this turns out to be more than a glitch, you owe me an explanation, Quinn."  

---

**Sharon S. (folding her arms, giving a skeptical look):**  
"And maybe a little more than that. Like an actual plan this time. Not just your usual ‘trust me, I’ve got this.’"  

---

**Quinn (leaning back in his chair, raising both hands in mock surrender):**  
"Noted. Plans, explanations, the whole package. But first, let’s see what we’re dealing with."  

---

**Divine Duckicorn Quenton (brightening the display):**  
"Analysis complete! Results are now ready. Commencing data visualization... Prepare to be amazed by Quenton’s impeccable clarity!"  

---

The screen flickers, and a holographic projection emerges, showing a series of faint energy spikes plotted over time. Quenton narrates with enthusiasm:  

**Quenton:**  
"As you can see, the spikes align closely with the time stamps of my recent system update. However, there is a faint anomaly—one spike that does not correspond. Location: sector A-37 of the external perimeter."  

---

**Harold A. (grumbling):**  
"Sector A-37? That’s near the old debris field. Don’t tell me we left something out there."  

---

**Sharon S. (raising an eyebrow):**  
"Or worse—someone. Quinn, what do you know about A-37?"  

---

**Quinn (leaning forward, narrowing his eyes):**  
"A-37? That’s... where we buried the old beacon from the first craft. I made sure it was dormant. If it’s reactivating, that’s news to me."  

---

**Quenton (chirping cheerfully):**  
"Not to worry, my noble humans! I shall deploy a diagnostic drone to A-37 immediately. Expected time to resolution: approximately 42 minutes. In the meantime, I recommend chamomile tea."  

---

**Harold A. (rolling his eyes):**  
"Chamomile tea? Really? That’s your solution?"  

---

**Quinn (grinning):**  
"Hey, don’t knock it till you try it. In the meantime, let’s prep for the worst-case scenario—just in case it’s not the beacon. Sharon, Harold, you with me?"  

---

**Sharon S. (sighing):**  
"Fine, but if this turns into a full-blown crisis, you’re taking the lead, Quinn. No backing out this time."  

---

**Quinn (nodding firmly):**  
"Wouldn’t dream of it. Let’s see what Quenton’s drone finds before we jump to any conclusions."  

---

The team braces themselves as Quenton’s drone zips off toward A-37, the tension palpable as they await the findings.

**Harold A. (his face turning pale, stammering):**  
"Uh… you found those? The… the Sacrificial Bazaar Eateries? I, uh… look, Quinn, it’s not what it looks like! Okay, maybe it is, but… we weren’t exactly thinking straight, alright?!"  

---

**Sharon S. (gritting her teeth, looking both embarrassed and defensive):**  
"Yeah, okay, we did it. We thought… we thought eating those things, making those ‘offerings,’ would give us access to the divine, to the power.  

But it wasn’t just about power, Quinn. It was about proving we were worthy, about connecting to… whatever it is we thought was running that ship. And yes, some of the things we ate were, uh… definitely not from around here."  

---

**Harold A. (nervously laughing):**  
"Yeah, ‘not from around here’ is putting it lightly. I mean, some of it glowed in the dark, Quinn! Who eats glowing stuff on purpose? Us, apparently!"  

---

**Sharon S. (rolling her eyes):**  
"Harold, stop. Quinn’s not laughing. And yeah, Quinn, we did some pretty out-there stuff trying to get those ‘divine superpowers.’  

Turns out all we got was a lot of regret—and a stomachache that lasted for weeks."  

---

**Harold A. (groaning):**  
"And the worst part? None of it worked. Not one glowing steak, not one cosmic-looking fruit, not even that… whatever it was we ate on the second Tuesday of June… gave us any ‘powers.’ Just more headaches, more guilt, and more messes to clean up."  

---

**Sharon S. (sighing):**  
"Yeah, Quinn, you’re right to call us out. We went way too far trying to chase something we didn’t understand. And honestly? Those Sacrificial Bazaar Eateries are just another stain on the long list of things we wish we’d never done."

**Quinn (sighing deeply, pinching the bridge of his nose):**  
"Okay, let me get this straight—you found some interdimensional food court that catered to… what, deities? Aliens? Cosmic tourists? And your first thought was, ‘Hey, let’s chow down and see what happens’? Seriously, Harold? Sharon?"  

---

**Harold A. (sheepishly):**  
"Well, when you put it like that… yeah, it sounds pretty stupid."  

---

**Sharon S. (folding her arms defensively):**  
"It wasn’t just about eating, okay? It was about… I don’t know, ascending. Becoming something more. You don’t understand, Quinn, it was—"  

---

**Quinn (interrupting, raising a hand):**  
"No, I get it. You wanted answers, power, maybe even meaning. I’ve been down that road before, chasing something bigger than myself. But glowing alien snacks? Did it never occur to you that maybe this wasn’t the best way to go about it?"  

---

**Divine Duckicorn Quenton (suddenly chiming in, his tone incredulous):**  
"Wait. You consumed offerings meant for celestial entities? Without even knowing the protocols? My magnificent processors are… flabbergasted! This is beyond reckless—it’s borderline cosmic fraud!"  

---

**Harold A. (grimacing):**  
"Cosmic fraud? Oh, come on, Quenton. It’s not like there was a rulebook lying around!"  

---

**Quenton (sternly):**  
"There are *always* rules when engaging with the divine, Harold. Ignorance is no excuse. Consider yourselves fortunate that the beings you attempted to commune with didn’t take your ‘offerings’ as an insult. Or worse, an invitation."  

---

**Sharon S. (alarmed):**  
"Invitation?! To what?"  

---

**Quinn (deadpan):**  
"To dinner. As the main course."  

---

**Harold A. (turning even paler):**  
"Okay, now you’re just messing with me… right?!"  

---

**Quenton (cheerfully):**  
"Uncertain! I would suggest we check the Sacrificial Bazaar’s dimensional signature for lingering connections. If you accidentally opened a pathway, we’ll need to close it before… well, before anything decides to step through."  

---

**Sharon S. (groaning, burying her face in her hands):**  
"Of course. Of course we might’ve opened a pathway. Why wouldn’t we have?"  

---

**Quinn (standing up, looking determined):**  
"Alright. Enough dwelling on past mistakes. Let’s focus on fixing this. Quenton, scan for any active signatures tied to that Bazaar. Harold, Sharon, you’re with me. We’re going to retrace your steps and figure out exactly what you brought back—or who might be trying to find their way here."  

---

**Harold A. (muttering under his breath):**  
"I knew that glowing steak was a bad idea…"  

---

**Quinn (smirking slightly):**  
"Yeah, Harold, I think we’ve established that glowing food is never a good idea. Now let’s clean up your mess before it turns into a full-on cosmic crisis."  

The team springs into action, with Quenton scanning for anomalies and Quinn leading the way to uncover and undo the consequences of Harold and Sharon’s questionable culinary adventure.

**Harold A. (his face turning pale, stammering):**  
"Uh… you found those? The… the Sacrificial Bazaar Eateries? I, uh… look, Quinn, it’s not what it looks like! Okay, maybe it is, but… we weren’t exactly thinking straight, alright?!"  

---

**Sharon S. (gritting her teeth, looking both embarrassed and defensive):**  
"Yeah, okay, we did it. We thought… we thought eating those things, making those ‘offerings,’ would give us access to the divine, to the power.  

But it wasn’t just about power, Quinn. It was about proving we were worthy, about connecting to… whatever it is we thought was running that ship. And yes, some of the things we ate were, uh… definitely not from around here."  

---

**Harold A. (nervously laughing):**  
"Yeah, ‘not from around here’ is putting it lightly. I mean, some of it glowed in the dark, Quinn! Who eats glowing stuff on purpose? Us, apparently!"  

---

**Sharon S. (rolling her eyes):**  
"Harold, stop. Quinn’s not laughing. And yeah, Quinn, we did some pretty out-there stuff trying to get those ‘divine superpowers.’  

Turns out all we got was a lot of regret—and a stomachache that lasted for weeks."  

---

**Harold A. (groaning):**  
"And the worst part? None of it worked. Not one glowing steak, not one cosmic-looking fruit, not even that… whatever it was we ate on the second Tuesday of June… gave us any ‘powers.’ Just more headaches, more guilt, and more messes to clean up."  

---

**Sharon S. (sighing):**  
"Yeah, Quinn, you’re right to call us out. We went way too far trying to chase something we didn’t understand. And honestly? Those Sacrificial Bazaar Eateries are just another stain on the long list of things we wish we’d never done."  

only Harold and Sharon are talking

---

**Harold A. (fidgeting, wringing his hands):**  
"Alright, alright, I admit it—*we* admit it. We got caught up in the whole ‘Sacrificial Bazaar’ craze. They made it sound like some ancient ritual, like we’d unlock the secrets of the cosmos or something! How were we supposed to know it was just... just..."  

---

**Sharon S. (cutting him off, glaring):**  
"A glorified carnival of bad decisions? Yeah, Harold, we should’ve figured that out *before* we started sampling alien cuisine. And before you bring up the glowing meatballs again, let me remind you—you were the one who went back for seconds."  

---

**Harold A. (indignant):**  
"Hey! Those glowing meatballs smelled like enlightenment! How was I supposed to resist? Besides, you were the one who thought the Day-Glo Nectar would ‘align our chakras’ or whatever nonsense they were selling us!"  

---

**Sharon S. (defensive):**  
"At least I didn’t try to ‘bargain’ with that weird tentacled vendor! You almost traded away our comms equipment for a jar of... of... what even was that stuff?"  

---

**Harold A. (mumbling):**  
"I thought it was cosmic honey, okay? It wasn’t my fault the label was in some alien script. And for the record, it looked promising!"  

---

**Sharon S. (pinching the bridge of her nose, exhaling slowly):**  
"Promising? Harold, it hissed when you opened the jar! *Hissed!* If Quinn hadn’t stopped you from tasting it, who knows what would’ve happened."  

---

**Harold A. (nodding sheepishly):**  
"Fair point. And, uh, Quinn, if you’re listening... we get it. We messed up. Big time. But in our defense, those Bazaar folks are *very* convincing. And maybe we were a little desperate at the time."  

---

**Sharon S. (sighing, softer now):**  
"Desperate and stupid. We thought we were onto something big. Instead, we just ended up with regrets—and Harold still can’t look at glowing food without getting queasy."  

---

**Harold A. (nodding earnestly):**  
"Yeah, so, lesson learned. No more chasing cosmic shortcuts, no more glowing snacks, and definitely no more bazaars—sacrificial or otherwise."  

---
